title: Tuesday, 30th April 2019

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Google reported revenue 3% below & EBIT 2% above consensus, and in standard form, didn’t offer much of anexplanation on the deceleration. Despite management flagging this to some degree in February, the revenue miss is likely to leave a cloud over the story for a while, as GOOG had not printed a deceleration of this magnitude in 4 years. Some US & EMEAweaknessis likely chalked up to Pixel declining Y/Y, but Sites growth of 19% ex-fx missed by 300bps & against a veryhealthy 1Q19 digital ad backdrop, investor questions linger. Further, core segment EBIT margin decline of 120bps Y/Y improved a tad from 2018’s cadence but was not enough to offset the topline. Stepping back, this isn’t a “FB July 2018” event, but we think the lack of disclosure will lead to more questions & certainly bring GOOG’s 25x P/E under scrutiny. We previously thought 2019 could be “like a 2015” whereby GOOG surprises on operating margin while maintaining solid revcadence, but it’s looking more like mid-2014 when revenue growth rates dropped off & questions went unanswered. Back then, the multiple re-rated to 13x forward non-GAAP, five full turns lower than currentlevels. We think shares remain rangebound near-term as investors digestresults.

Grouchmonkey Fairly positive trading update but down c 3%?
BE11:22am

I think that's 25x trailing PE but 18 forward PE?

AMALtd Look at Amazon jump in Ad (+34% yoy), it might be a tough battle down the road

Google missed every revenue line by 1.5%-4% for 1Q,and we were below consensus. We have toimagine that some of the deceleration is deliberate around product changes, and some is Google resetting the bar. Network trends are likely to get worse as Yahoo and AOL drop out of AFS going forward.

BE11:24am

Citi:

BE11:24am

Alphabet delivered a worse-than-expected 1Q19 report, with revenue
below consensus (largely hit by FX headwinds), while Operating Income margin and adj. EBITDA margin were better than expected if the one-time EC fine charges are excluded. Google Properties’ Gross Revs of $25.7bn grew 19% y/y FXN, and Total Gross Profit of $20.3bn grew 15% y/y. Excluding the 1x legal charge, operating
expense (ex-SBC) was down 12% q/q while adj. EBITDA margin of 45% was above consensus. Mgmt reiterated that capex growth will decelerate meaningfully this year but expected S&M to pick up in 2Q and Other Bets OpEx to increase y/y in 2019. The company repurchased $3.0bn of shares (vs. $2.7bn in the last qtr). Taken together, despite the weak 1Q results, we still believe GOOGL can post a 3-yr forward topline CAGR of 18% and generate GAAP EPS of $50 in 2020, which we believe continues to support a target ex-cash ‘20E P/E of 23x and, with ~$200/sh in forecasted net cash, a 12-month target price of $1,325. With the stock trading down after hours, we maintain our Buy rating.

Patience @Grouchmonkey - DS Smith still yielding under 4%. Perhaps positive update reduces likelihood of becoming a bid target?
11:24 am
BE11:25am

You'll note the common theme here is "oh, bad, but buy anyway yes?"

BE11:25am

Oppenheimer:

BE11:25am

We are lowering our price target to $1,342 from $1,435, but maintaining our
Outperform rating on valuation. Despite weaker ad results and lower core margins y/ y, GOOG is a cash cow, dominating search, and compounding its core business, with numerous new initiatives (see business updates) at just 11x '20E EBITDA and 21x FCF (and even cheaper ex. cash). Net revenue +19% y/y, ex. FX, 2% below Street expectations and a deceleration from 4Q's 23%, but operating income was 5% above the Street on lower COGS, ex TAC and when excluding the European Commission fine. Mgmt expects headcount and capex growth to be meaningful lower than in 2018, while still planning to significantly invest in content, cloud and hardware.

VV75 I think it's more fear of missing out with the faang stocks
11:25 am
BE11:25am

MOST.

BE11:26am

Impact on Thesis: GOOGL’s 1Q ex FX Websites revenue came in 1% lower than our estimate…growing 19% Y/Y, the first time GOOGL has grown ex FX less than 20% in 17 quarters (Q3:14). GOOGL pointed to "the timing of product changes in ads" as one of the factors that drove the growth deceleration…but didn't provide any more clarity around what the changes were, whether the impact will be linear by quarter, or whether there will be more changes to come. The fact is we aren’t sure what changes GOOGL made in the quarter that drove the
deceleration and this is something the Street must figure out. While EBIT,
EBITDA, and FCF were all stronger than expected, the forward growth
trajectory of Websites revenue (given the scale and leverage in this ~$100bn annualized business) is likely to remain top of mind to determining long-term valuation.

BE11:26am

JPMorgan:

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Overall, we expect GOOGL shares to be under pressure in the near-term given sub-20% revenue growth & downward earnings revisions. As noted above, the exact drivers of GOOGL’s slowing topline are unclear, & we believe frustration around GOOGL’s lack of transparency will only increase. That being said, GOOGL has maintained 20%+ growth for a very long time—off a large base—and now represents roughly 1/3 of the global online ad market. It also faces increased advertising competition from AMZN, at least on the margin. Our 2019/2020 revenue & GAAP EPS all come down about 2% as improved Other Bets losses partly offset slower Google Segment revenue growth. We maintain our Overweight rating, but prefer other FANG names Facebook, Amazon, & Netflix to Google. Our price target increases modestly from $1,250 to $1,310 on 23x Google Segment 2020E GAAP EPS of $56.93.

Irish HF guy @wayneJ, the thing about google is the relentless growth across the search engine, youtube and mobile devices. At some stage, perhaps it halts. BE11:31am

DS Smith has released a pre close trading update for ytd FY19 (April end). Management notes that performance is line with its expectations. The tone appears to have softened with regard to volume growth which is described as “ongoing growth” and share gains compared to “good growth” and confidence of “continued strong demand”. While all regions have generated volume growth management notes that strength in the UK, Italy and Poland has been partially offset by some volume weakness in export led markets including Germany.
Management has reiterated that group margins are expected to progress further in H219 and operating cashflow will be stronger yoy. The integration of Europac is going well. While noting the current economic uncertainties management believes the business is well positioned with a focus on “enhanced cost and efficiency improvements” which may point to some self-help efforts above and beyond synergies from recent deals.
Not a major surprise to see the volume commentary has deteriorated as has already been reflected in the pricing backdrop. While DS Smith’s short paper position should give it a temporary cost tailwind in Q419 and Q120, corrugated price decreases will impact profitability as we move into H220 and FY21 for which there is material downside risk to profits. We remain cautious.

BE11:31am

And Stifel:

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Trading is in line with management expectations underpinned by continued volume growth, market share gains and strong e-commerce positioning. Box volume growth was 3.2% in 1H; our conversation with management this morning suggests this slowed in the latter stages of the year reflecting a trickier macro backdrop.
Germany was singled out as an area of weakness but the UK, Italy and Poland remained very strong. Margin progression has been good in 2H but lower paper prices are likely to impact our FY20 expectations, which we will review in due course. All in all, today's statement strikes a more measured tone than we had become used to from DS Smith. This said, valuation is undemanding and there is dividend support to the share price with a 4.7% FY20E dividend yield and FCF yield of c.9%.

wayneJ @IrishHF / Tom / AMA - What I find fascinating is that the same arguments would have applied at the height of their dominance relating to Yahoo and to AOL?

BE11:32am

We expect a more substantive update with FY19 results on 13 June 2019. We believe that SMDS could: 1) upgrade medium-term EBITA margin guidance to c9-11% (from c8-10%); 2) update on the Europac acquisition & synergies (100 days of ownership in May); 3) outline its capital allocation priorities, confidence in cash generation, and views on leverage given 2.3x FY19E net debt to EBITDA (or c1.9x pro-forma for £400m plastics disposal); 4) highlight attractive medium-term demand tailwinds; and 5) update the market on European macro demand/pricing for containerboard/boxes.

BE11:39am

Here's Morgan Stanley to summarise what was said.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

The company says there has been a further weakening in market demand since the start of FY20, particularly in the Regions where it generates ~80% of revenue. It therefore expects weak UK market RevPAR (unquantified), greater investment (including capacity addition of 3-4k rooms), c. £10m operational dis-synergies following the sale of Costa (already announced), cost savings of £40-50m more than offset by £70m cost increases, and a £4m increase in German losses (already announced). We recently downgraded our FY20 RevPAR assumption to -4.0% from -2.5% (note). We estimate that every 1% on RevPAR is £8-13m to EBIT, and that every 1,000 new rooms is ~£8-10m to EBIT. This suggests a £40-50m PBT headwind, suggesting modest downside to our £415m PBT estimate (but more to consensus at £443m). Previous guidance was for flat PBT for FY20, which has been dropped. The company also flags that IFRS 16 will have a ~£20m hit to FY19 PBT, around 7%, although it is non-cash. Whitbread shares have re-rated sharply this year from 13.7x to 17.9x cal 20e P/E and 9.3x to 10.3x EBITDA and we no longer see the valuation as that attractive and rate the shares Equal-weight.

wayneJ “acute period of political and economic uncertainty” - management was more explicit verbally - it is Brexit.
1966AndAllThat Goog employs brilliant people, at PE 20 IMHO thats worth investing in. The changes hinted at might have been deliverately hobbling the engagement algo as too many people were being sent down dangerous rabbit holes. The recent Games initiative may be a real winner...I hope so as very long AMD and on tenterhooks for their results this evening
BE11:41am

And Numis.

BE11:41am

Outlook & Guidance: With its Q3 results, management had suggested "we expect underlying profit before tax in FY20 to be consistent with this year". However, STR data for March to date shows regional RevPAR (midscale & economy) was -4.4% and WTB is now planning on a weaker performance. It is also guiding to £40-50m cost savings (from the £120m 3y programme announced in January) but a pick-up in gross cost inflation from £55m to £70m. Our current assumption of -2% RevPAR therefore looks too optimistic and we see mid single digit downside to consensus estimates as a result.
● The £2bn tender offer is an important part of the return of capital (£2.5bn) following the disposal of Costa (for £3.8bn). This will be launched after WTB's AGM on 19th June and at this stage it intends to pursue a "variable price" offer with the price range based on VWAP in a short period up to and including the point of completion.
● Valuation & recommendation: WTB trades on a 2020 P/E of 18.5x and EV/EBITDA of 10.8x. We recognise the structural growth prospects in both the UK and Germany and the strength of its operating model and returns. However, in the near term weak market RevPAR and negative earnings momentum will weigh on the share price in our view.

BE11:48am

Esimates aren't changing and the fiscal Q1 gets tougher

BE11:48am

Caz can summarise.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Greene King has reported +2.9% Pub Company LFL sales growth for the 52 weeks to 28th April, vs. JPMe -
2.2% LFL for FY19. The implied Q419 (16 weeks from 6th January) LFL was +2.4% v JPMe of -0.8%,
compared to c. -2.6% last year (for the similar period) and c. +4.2% in the 12 week period to January 6th.
Although this is a good result, we think it will have largely been priced in given the weak comp and the
favourable Easter weather (share price has gained

4% over the past five trading days).

 Pub Company LFL in Q419 (16 weeks) of +2.4% were buoyed by exceptionally sunny weather coinciding
with the long Bank Holiday weekend. Although Easter 2018 (straddling March and April) was quite strong,
with managed pub LFLs of +4.6%, the weather this year was materially better, and LFLs were again up,
+4.6%. In addition, the “Beast from the East” established a weak comp in March 2018. Underlining this, the
Coffer Peach Business tracker swung from a -2.0% managed pub LFL in March 2018 to +4.0% in March this
year. We note GNK has again outperformed the tracker in this (roughly calendar Q1) period (+2.9% v~+1.3%
for managed pubs).
 Pub Partners FY19 LFL net income was +1.6%, and LFL profit was -1.4%.
 Brewing; total brewed volumes were +0.9%, with own-brewed volumes -3.4%, compared to the UK ale
market at -4.2%.
 Cost savings: Greene King is on-track to limit net cost inflation to £10m-20m as previously guided.
 Refinancing; In H219 51% of the Spirit debenture was repaid (£393m), with GNK raising £250m at 3.6%
through its securitisation, creating headroom within the RCF for future debenture amortization payments.
 Disposal programme: Described as “broadly on-track”.
 Outlook; Greene King expects adj. PBT to be in the range of £244m-247m for FY19 (JPMe £242m).

BE11:49am

Read across: GNK operates nationally (with a skew to the South East), and so this LFL result provides a
direct read across to other drink-led national pub companies, such as Marston’s and JD Wetherspoon. The
Easter weather, coupled with the exceptionally weak comp from last year, sets up the pub companies with a
drink bias to have performed well during the most recent period.

And certain for types of travellers the "live-in" arrangement is a bonus, you get to see the actual life of the place
BE11:49am

And Citi.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

GNK has reported FY Pub Co LFLs (74% of EBIT) to end April of
+2.9%, a modest slowdown from the +3.2% after 36 weeks with the last 16 weeks at +2.4%. Although still outperforming the industry, this may disappoint relatively high expectations following strong industry data in March (+3.8%) and favourable weather over Easter. We estimate that the group’s outperformance of the Coffer Peach industry data has faded from c190bp to c140bp in the most recent period as the group laps its VSQ investment from last year. Net cost inflation guidance has been maintained at £10m-£20m and we expect Pub Co margins to decline c10bp. Overall the group is on track to deliver underlying PBT of £244m-£247m in line with Reuters consensus of £245m.

BE11:58am

11:58 am
BE11:58am

RBC ran the figures on that earlier in the week.

BE11:58am

SBO: In this note we look at a scenario where the Souters (26% of shares) proceeded to a scenario where some other investors did not value the potential of the business and its equity FCF. We then assume (purely for the scenario) these 26% holders attempt to take the business private by bidding to de-list via a 'Souters Buy Out' (‘SBO’).

BE11:59am

Our SBO assumes: [1] The shares are taken private at average price of the last 12 months – a 30% premium. [2] All other free float shareholders also exit [some perhaps might stay involved, reducing the cost of the SBO and its subsequent debt leverage]. [3] Bus EBITDA from Newcastle and Manchester is all lost to bus franchising in FY21E. (4) Gross debt is refinanced at ~6.5% interest rates. (5) Gross bus capex is kept at 11% revenues after FY20E; (6) London’s buoyant industrial real estate market sees freehold London bus depots sold and then leased back at a 3.5-4.0% implied yield. We assume that after the SBO the company makes a 90% dividend pay-out.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

In our scenario we see an outcome where:
High debt strain: (1) ND/EBITDA is high – at 6.4x, falling slowly by 5.9x by 2025E (5.5x if no Dividends were paid). (2) If Manchester and Newcastle EBITDA was not lost ND/EBITDA falls to 5.5x 2025E.
But little opportunity cost for the Souters’ on lost dividend income: On our Manchester and Newcastle EBITDA exited scenario, dividend opportunity cost would nonetheless be small – at least on a spreadsheet. In this scenario, average DPS would lift to 9.9p over the five years after SBO (from our listed base case at 7.7p). However, there would be a risk to real life events a spreadsheet cannot capture and thus from high levels of debt strain.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

.... though if you want the York Notes on structure:

BE12:04pm

 Equity tranche [US$400m]: Firm pricing (90% of equity tranche) to be
determined via a book-build on 30 April. The remaining balance raised
via placing and open offer. The total equity tranche is expected to be
completed and funds available by 23 May. Conditional on: (i)
shareholder approval, (ii) placing and open offer becoming
unconditional, and (iii) successful issuance of CB.
 Convertible Bond [US$400-644m]: Senior, unsecured 5% 8yr CB sized
at US$400-644m. The range reflects the proportion of the outstanding
$244m CB (due Nov’23, 8.5% coupon) that is rolled into the new CB.
Current YTM is 10% (incl. PIK). Conversion premium 20-25% (which
will be adjusted for the equity placement price) with issuer call at 150%
trigger after 2 years, and 130% trigger after 4 years. Conditional on: (i)
successful completion of equity tranche, and (ii) shareholder approval.
 High yield bond [US$500m]: Senior, secured US$500m HY bond.
Coupon rate will be subject to market conditions, with deal closure
“expected to occur this summer” (presentation slides indicate proceeds
between May-July). Coupon interest on first issue of historically
“comparable” project (e.g. FMG) is 9.75-10.625%.
 Revolving Credit Facility [US$2,500m]: 7 year tenor at Libor + 500bp
(current 12m Libor ~2.7% on Bloomberg). RCF expected to be drawn in
three tranches once the project has substantially de-risked. Indicative
timing is drawdowns of US$1,000m, US$1,000m and US$500m in
2021, 2022 and 2023, respectively. For each US$500m drawn from the
RCF, a senior secured HY bond will be issued. (The HY issuance will
not necessarily be issued at the same terms as the initial HY bond).
Additionally, each US$500m drawn will release US$200m in additional
RCF liquidity (e.g. US$1,000m of additional RCF liquidity once
US$2,500m of HY bonds issued). Conditional on: (i) successful equity
raise, (ii) net US$400m from CB issuance, (iii) US$500m HY bond
issuance, and (iv) satisfaction of CPs.
